text: Hi <@U0162CX5SH1>, I’m so sorry this happened to you, it’s really frustrating. It happened to me with a potential client recently after I wrote a 500-word sample, despite them saying they’d send me a contract by the end of the next day. I suspect they just changed their minds and didn’t want to send a rejection. It sucks, but ghosting seems to be how people handle it.

text:
Anyone use Asana to manage their content calendar? 

I’m in a situation where I have to test the platform out in earnest but struggling to figure out how to do less manual data entry. So my intent is to find some examples of how folks are leveraging Asana (which is also my roundabout way of saying I’m well aware of other platforms and tools).

text: I think Asana's useful if you are managing multiple clients and want to see all of projects together in a calendar. Plus, for larger scale projects need to set up milestones/subtasks. But for internal review you'll need an additional piece whether it's Google Docs, Wrike, etc.

elements.text: I think Asana's useful if you are managing multiple clients and want to see all of projects together in a calendar. Plus, for larger scale projects need to set up milestones/subtasks. But for internal review you'll need an additional piece whether it's Google Docs, Wrike, etc.

text: I am just starting the switch this month with my team. We used Google Sheets for management, but are switching to Asana this month. From what I researched, explore, and tried out, I believe it will only simplify the process we already had in place. And it will be easier for the entire team. But, I'll see the results soon enough :smile:

text:
<@U01A0BPDS1X> The only pre-requisite for most assistant positions I hire for or have helped hire for is great written communication. Everything else can/should be taught or well-documented as a part of a thorough process anyway (in a way that’s almost fool proof for someone with a reasonable understanding of the business).

(I know this was directed @ Kat, but I thought I might as well weigh in too:)

text:
I’m curious how other b2b folks use webinars in their funnel (do you use them to generate sales opps? is it more purely top-of-funnel lead gen?) + handle programming.

Would love to hear your perspective/tips — or if anyone’s willing, a quick informational zoom chat! :pray:

elements.text:
I’m curious how other b2b folks use webinars in their funnel (do you use them to generate sales opps? is it more purely top-of-funnel lead gen?) + handle programming.

Would love to hear your perspective/tips — or if anyone’s willing, a quick informational zoom chat!

text:
:wave:  Hey Janet! I launched the webinar channel for a childcare app company (HiMama) and we’re currently running 2 types of webinar content:

1. *TOFU webinars that are “panel/interview” style on a trending topic*. We do these featuring a mixed bag of customers and consultants. This is so we have sessions that are more peer2peer knowledge sharing and more instructional stuff led by a consultant (and they get to plug their services). 
2. *Customer only webinars for upselling opps* - product walkthroughs, SaaS change management implementation tips (child care is not a very tech savvy niche). I’m currently testing this channel to build the personal brand of our Customer Success team in the child care space.
Hope that helps and feel free to shoot me a message if you’d like to set up a Zoom call!

elements.text: Hey Janet! I launched the webinar channel for a childcare app company (HiMama) and we’re currently running 2 types of webinar content:
TOFU webinars that are “panel/interview” style on a trending topic

. We do these featuring a mixed bag of customers and consultants. This is so we have sessions that are more peer2peer knowledge sharing and more instructional stuff led by a consultant (and they get to plug their services).
Customer only webinars for upselling opps

- product walkthroughs, SaaS change management implementation tips (child care is not a very tech savvy niche). I’m currently testing this channel to build the personal brand of our Customer Success team in the child care space.
Hope that helps and feel free to shoot me a message if you’d like to set up a Zoom call!

text:
Agree with everything <@URA4VBQ2X> mentioned – written comms is the primary means of contact, so def a trait we’re looking for. A make or break is also efficiency (although very hard to detect off the bat). 

Usually start by feeling them out, asking if they’ve done similar tasks, but a trial period will really determine if it’s a good fit. Best of luck to your wife on her new path! :+1::skin-tone-2:

mentioned – written comms is the primary means of contact, so def a trait we’re looking for. A make or break is also efficiency (although very hard to detect off the bat).

text:
Hey <@UPM5604VC>, our SEO Team extracts these kinds of things from time to time for us, Either using Ahrefs of ScreamingFrog I think. Sometimes our developers are able to mass-change URLs (e.g. when we moved from a subdomain to a catalog), but then we’re doing plenty of those manually. E.g. recently we’ve finished editing 1,5k URLs that had .html in them and should have had that trimmed.

Right now whenever I update a piece of content, I check for any internal links and backlinks and see if any is broken or there’s a redirect chain so that I can edit them.

elements.text: Hey

, our SEO Team extracts these kinds of things from time to time for us, Either using Ahrefs of ScreamingFrog I think. Sometimes our developers are able to mass-change URLs (e.g. when we moved from a subdomain to a catalog), but then we’re doing plenty of those manually. E.g. recently we’ve finished editing 1,5k URLs that had .html in them and should have had that trimmed.

Right now whenever I update a piece of content, I check for any internal links and backlinks and see if any is broken or there’s a redirect chain so that I can edit them.

text:
I write and review UX and app copy too <@U014FMGRKQA>. I found the initial beginner's course on the UX Writing Hub (<https://uxwritinghub.com>) very useful - contemplating getting into their full-time course. I also follow Yuval Keshtcher and Torrey Podmajersky.

Books - I love Scott Kubie's book 'Writing for Designers' and Kinneret Yifrah's book 'Microcopy: The complete guide'.

I post everyday on the intersection of design, copy, and product on LI and Twitter. Not to self-plug, but I hope I can help you or anyone looking to begin in these roles with any more help you need. Cheers!

attachments.title: UX Writing Hub | A place UX Writers can finally call home
attachments.text: UX Writing courses, blog, newsletter, podcast, job board, and training that are all dedicated to helping UX writers and product teams to create better UX.
